His attitude was so positive and even said that we'd get our lassis free if we didn't absolutely love them (we did!). I only wish that my lassi was a little creamier and more consistent but I still really enjoyed it. Also, if you are vegan, they can also make their lassis with almond milk instead of yogurt, which is the traditional base. I would definitely come back!
the food is good. the owner is nice.but i think its little expensive but cheap compare to other Indian foods. and the guy makes money. next day i had an amazing time in bathroom. so thank you hassan.

Mood Cafe is exactly as everyone here describes and is equally wonderful. It's a one-man operation, so not the place to go if you're in a hurry. It's a bit of a spectacle in itself to watch the chaat coming together - a little dance behind the counter to assemble all of the various ingredients. We got a punjabi chaat and the crazy chaat - couldn't really tell the difference between the two, but it didn't matter a bit because it was really good. Also, the fig lassi was completely and totally off the hook - this could quickly become and obsession. Good, good, damn good food, and not at all expensive. Just try it. Now.
Outstanding Customer service!! Phenomenal Cucumber Lassi!!! Be prepared to want both the lassi and the chaat bowl....wishing I skipped breakfast at this very momenthaha

This place is the best! The owner was so friendly. He offered me to pay after in case I don't like it. But food and drink(custom made) was delicious. Authentic, friendly, delicious, inexpensive. Try it if you are near by!

One of best lassi's I've ever tasted. I had mango one but got a chance to taste rose flavor one which was awesome. Hassan was warm and welcoming he also gave us two free lassi's cause we ordered our chaats spicy so there you go ...a tip to get a complimentary free drink... just say make it spicy

If you consider yourself a foodie this has to be on your list. I didn't know what chaat was, I don't like fruits mixed with my food, lassis never humored me but none of this mattered. The chicken chaat with salad was easily the most interesting meal I've had in months. It all works, somehow.

We got an almond pineapple lassi and it was amazing. We also got a strawberry pineapple. Amazing.

The service is great but I didn't think of it as a typical service. The owner is very interactive in that he's not doing you a service by providing you food but he's just living life and happens to be serving you some great food.

5 stars justified.

My friends and I had never had chaat before. The owner was able to size that up immediately and kindly took the time to explain the dish to us. We ordered the chicken, beef, and veggie chaats, all of which were delicious! Such a delightful assortment of flavors and textures. Mmmm! The lassis were also delicious. I'd only ever had mango and strawberry before. We ordered the fig, the rose, and the...nectarine, I want to say? Honestly, I bet every single one of them is amazing and it doesn't even matter. I wish I could go back, but Denton is a long ways from Philly!

Hassan is one of the most friendly restaurant owners I've met in my entire life, he is completely devoted to ensuring that customers have the best eating experience that he can provide. I was unfamiliar with both chaat and lassi but he gave a swift explanation of what to it expect, he offered to make as many chaats as needed until I found one that I liked. The food was great but what really sets this place apart was the kindness and enthusiasm of the owner--Hassan made an already excellent meal into the perfect end to a long day in 95 traffic.

Good to be back in the neighborhood.  Been meaning to check this place out and finally had the time.

Other reviews are on point.  Not much to add.  Hasan is amazing - good dude, good food.

Opted for mango lassi and didnt disappoint.

This place is AMAZING!!!!!! Over 60 different lassis, 30 different chats- all unique and delicious! Even more- the customer service is on point. Very friendly and different from what I'm used to in Philadelphia area restaurants! Great vegetarian options and easy to find free street parking.

I've lived down the block from this place for about a year and stopped in for a late lunch about a week ago. The employee was very helpful and recommend I just say my desired level of spiciness instead of ordering off the somewhat confusing (and overwhelming) menu. And my meal was delicious. Had the vegetarian chatt- perfect combo of sweet, salty and spicy with a nice crunch. It was amazing how every bite had a different taste and texture.

This spot is legit. They have ALL of the fixin's you can imagine for some good quality chaat. If you're new to the chaat game, just ask the dude who works there for a suggestion. Counter to what some people have said, the dudes who work there are very helpful and friendly and excited to make you a delicious authentic snack. My roomie and I went with the "Crazy chaat" which literally has everything you can imagine in it, from melons, to raisins to chana masala and puff rice. I was a bit worried that it might have been an overload, but I was so wrong. That ish was SO bomb, I wanted more!

Absolutely amazing. It's a small place, but carries so much heart. The guy was amazing and so kind. He was very opening and informative to people who didn't have too much experience with Chaat. 

Food was delicious and the drinks were perfect. I highly recommend this place 10 times over.

It's high time I wrote a review for Mood cafe. The chat here is unique and Hasan is very creative when it comes to combining different ingredients. Love the paneer chat and pani puri is an all time fav! Don't get me started on the amazing variety of lassis here.. It's difficult to pick one but no matter what you choose it is always wonderful! I have recommended this place to several of my friends who are now regulars here :)
Vegan piña colada lassi, yes please. Custom made chaat from the nicest business owner in west Philly. Yes please.  I love chaat, I love the vegan options and I love Mr. Hassan.

When I take the first bite, I rarely go "MMMMM!" This rare moment occurred today at Mood Cafe. My friend and I were the only ones there so the owner took his time explaining the chaats and created two chaats that he thought we would enjoy. I had the beef chaat with hot sauce which I thought was better than my friend's crazy chicken chaat (chicken was cold too). It definitely has that spicy, crunchy, savory and sweet combination. I want to try the lassis when I go back. I would definitely bring my friends here!

This place is so bomb......the owner was very helpful and insightful of the menu! He makes his own rise water smoothie that's to die for! He is the nicest, funniest, person I've came across in a long time!

Visiting a friend in NJ and saw the reviews to this amazing place so we drove here. It was well worth driving through traffic. Amazing chaat. We got the samosa chaat and chicken tikka chaat. There was enough chutney and yogurt to cover every bite. The combination of flavors work so well together. The best part was that the owner was so incredibly nice and he cared about your experience. He told us to pay at the end and if we don't like it, we don't pay. He gave us extra mango lassi so both my husband and I could try it. He offered my baby kheer and carrot halwa for free. I hope that he opens up a location in Orange county or LA. My husband says "best chaat he's ever had and possibly the best food he's had on our east coast trip. Try the rose lassi. Tastes like liquefied kulfi."

Desi Village, Inc. is venturing into a third location along Baltimore Avenue in West Philadelphia, only not a restaurant. Mood Cafe, a coffee shop with South Indian flair, is set to open in early May.

I had a conversation with the owner of Mood Cafe as he was supervising the exterior being painted the customary orange of many of the Desi Village, Inc. locations.

Unlike Desi Village and Desi Chaat House, the emphasis at Mood Cafe will be on beverages. Cafe standards like coffee, tea, lattes and espresso will be available as well as Chaat House favorites including freshly squeezed juices.  Unlike other locations, plans are in the works for nearly a dozen different varieties of lassi. Chaat will also be available.

It will be interesting to see if this location becomes an option for residents south of Baltimore Avenue for whom The Satellite, The Green Line, and The Gold Standard are not viable options.

I barely review anything and I had to review Mood Cafe.  The rose lassi and the chaat were two of the best things I have ever tasted!  Owner is so friendly and helpful.  He made me my first chaat ever and I LOVED it.

I love Indian food and never had chaat before. It's like a street food dish with everything tossed in: crispy won-ton noodle things, radish, meats, tons of veggies, tons of different sauces. It attacks every taste bud. It was total comfort food, very reasonably priced and had a good portion size.

The owner is SUPER nice. We told him it was our first time and he described all the ingredients and styles. Helped us choose our first chaats and spices. Also... the bottled water is free to everyone. And if we didn't like anything it was free on the house. I love his confidence and enthusiasm for his product.

Food and service alone are worth checking this out. But I also loved the style of this cafe: I'm also a huge fan of places that do 1 or 2 things really well. Mood cafe only serves up Chaat dishes and lassi smoothies. But there's like 30 variations of each. I can't wait to go back and try something crazier in the chaat category.

For what this place is - it doesn't get any better. The chaat is so fresh and uplifting - I went with the kefta myself on the recommendation of the owner. It was an unexpectedly full meal and my friend and I got to chat with the owner about how he keeps his customers happy and gets consistently high ratings on places like yelp. Maybe I was convinced by him - he does have an incredibly large variety and the food is pretty healthy, definitely unique, and comes out in seconds with a ton of flavor. The environment in unassuming and he's a cool guy to chat with. But I stick with the food - the only way you won't like this place will be if you don't like chaat. If you do - you're in good hands.

To some, joy may be found in dining at a fancy restaurant with ordinary service and food for a steep price. To me, bliss is discovering a jewel in the rough where the service and food is indeed extraordinary for less than $10! I've always wondered but now I understand why Mood Café is rated the best restaurant in the city of Philadelphia.

1. First of all, the food here reflects the owner's philosophies. Made with love and care, the intricate blend of ingredients is truly magical. Each flavor is bright, distinct, and amazing. I cannot recommend a specific lassi or chaat because if you choose from any of the literally hundreds of possible combinations, you will not be disappointed. Although Hassan always says kindly that you can have your money back anytime if you do not approve, no one has ever done so.

2. From the wildly popular rose lassi to the many fruits in the chaats, every single food item on the menu is made fresh from scratch. It makes you wonder if he is actually hiding a huge secret elaborate garden somewhere?! 

3. Vegan, lactose-intolerant, and can't eat spicy? No worries fellow patrons. At Mood Café, it's all about you, the valuable customer. And amazingly, it doesn't matter what you prefer, because you'll find out it all will taste oh so delicious!

4. Hassan personifies what all business owners should strive to become: friendly, accommodating, down to earth, and funny. When you leave Mood Café, you'll have both your stomach and heart content with incredible food and genuine love. 

I honestly wish Mood Cafe was more common in the world. People like Hassan working hard to make the best food with the best service possible, not the cash that comes with it. Simplicity and perfection at every level. Bravo!

I don't think there is anything I can say about this place that hasn't been said already. This place definitely deserves the rating it receives.

This is not only the place where you get amazingly delicious Indian/Pakistani street flavors but also a touch of south Asian hospitality.

I live a few blocks from this place and visit mood  cafe quite often. The chats are always delicious and so are Lassis. If you are ever confused about what to order, just ask Hasan. He is super friendly and always have great recommendations

Living in Cedar Park, I figured I just had to go here. And with all the positive reviews, how could I not? 

All the other yelpers are right. He is the man! My boyfriend and I went on a blistery cold December day, and we were his only customers that strolled thru the door. He explained what a chaat was very simply, and stated that if we liked it, we pay for it. If not, then he doesn't want our money. But with such nice service, how can I NOT pay him? Even if I wasn't the biggest fan, I can't just leave him without paying. So service - amazing, nice, comforting and welcoming

FOOD - this is probably a personal preference. I thought it was just OK. It is extremely flavorful, almost too flavorful? Too much was going on in my mouth. It was also cold, which I wasn't expecting. But that's probably what a chaat is. So it's cold, spicy, cilantro-y, sour/lemony, curry/indian flavory, yogurty all at the same time. The flavors were great, but just not my cup of tea. 
LASSI - was delicious. Mint + honey, do something different, don't just do mango! He has everyyything under the sea. He picked the mint fresh too :)

I probably won't return just due to personal preference. But if my friends from outta town wanted a good chaat, I would take them there. Or a good lassi in the spring/summer time? Hell yes.

Love, love, love!  My boyfriend introduced me to Hassan's place down the street, Desi Chaat House, and it was love at first bite!  Then I came in and met Hassan, and he was so alluring and passionate about his chaat's that it just keeps getting better and better the more I experience his sweet, savory, delicious chaat!  

If you have no idea what chaat is, go in and tell Hassan, and just enjoy the show!  His excitement and passion will lead you to the perfect meal for you!  It's such an awesome experience, and nothing like anything else in Philly.  I am in love and I'll shout it from the roof tops!   

Favorite Chaat at Mood: Vegetarian Mastana!  
Favorite Lassi at Mood:  Guava with Almond Milk 

I will note though - if you like the samosa chaat at Mood, try it at Desi Chaat House too, cause that's the only one I still need to go down the street for!  :)

Consider this another rave review for a small but amazing place.

First and foremost, we walked in and looked at the menu. I'm sure we looked lost. Hasan, being the incredibly kind and helpful man that he is, asked "first timers?" And proceeded to walk us through exactly what a chaat is and what a lassi is, then helped us pick what to get according to our likes.

I seriously can't sing Hasan's praises enough. I was writing a paper on culture for my class and he was nice enough to sit down with me and answer some questions. It's clear that he puts alot of pride and love into his food. Not to mention that he's a joy to talk to!

To the food: I got a samosa chaat and a mango lassi. M got a chicken chaat and a blueberry lassi. The samosa was slightly spicy and delicious, and the chaat was so good. Every bite was different, so with every bite both M and I kept saying "mmmmm!" 

We also got to try the rice pudding which is quite possibly the best rice pudding I ever had. We're already planning on returning to try more chaats and lassis!

I really love that they make vegan lassis! Mint and honey has been my favorite combination so far. Very excellent on a hot day with some spicy chaat. 

This has to be the friendliest cafe in all of Philly. The gentleman behind the counter is so patient to explain the different items to customers who are out of their element. Love it! He's always cheerful (but not in a sleazy way) and accommodating.

This is probably the most confusing thing I've ever eaten. But it was really good!!

The chaat is so interesting. It's a mix of tender meat, chickpeas, mango chunks, radish slices, raisins, and fried strips covered in raita, mint/cilantro chutney, and sweet tamarind chutney. The owner claimed the green sauce was spicy, but I literally tasted no heat, but definitely lots of flavor! I loved the chaat. I got the chicken tikka chaat, and it was just bursting with sweet, tangy, salty, yummy flavor. So unique.

The rice pudding they have in the fridge was also super delicious! Much thicker than normal kheer, and so rich with condensed milk flavor. The pistachios on top were a nice touch and a great texture contrast from the thick pudding.

They also gave us free bottled water :) That shouldn't excite me as much as it does, but yay!

Mood Cafe is super good, super interesting, and definitely something to try!

It was good to be back in the old neighborhood again up along Baltimore Avenue in West Philly.  Things have changed around my old home at 48th and Balto, mostly for the better.  I was here a few months ago sampling the heat at Chili Szechuan, and this time I was back to meet up with Yelp friends at Mood Café, the Chaat & Lassi emporium on the point at 46th Street.  Lucky for me, they were delayed arriving, and I had an opportunity for a long talk with Hasan, the owner/chef/creative genius behind the concept and the counter that is Mood.  I got the $.50 tour, and an autobiography worthy of Horatio Alger. 

While I had eaten Chaat (pronounced, "Chart") before, it had never been like this.  Hasan has taken what is basically a common street food in India and turned it into an adventure in eating.  It comes at you in several dimensions - taste, texture, hardness/softness, shape, spice, food group, color and surprise.  It sat before me the most colorful assortment of edibles imaginable.  I had the Salad Chaat with Chicken, but there was so much happening inside that take out container that the meat was forgotten in the exploration of what was going on with all the reds, yellows, stars, logs, crispies, noodles, dried fruit, nuts, fresh mango, greens, feta cheese, chili sauces, curry notes, etc.  It is difficult to describe all the hyperactivity in that bowl.  Imagine an Indian version of Trail Mix thrown into a salad rather than croutons. If he had tossed in some M & M's I would not have been shocked.  This baby was Buh-Buh-Buh-Bizzzeee!!!

And, bottom line, it was awesome. We tried each others dishes, and all were unique and captivating. 

And, that does not even get into the Lassis.  More than 60 varieties of cool, creamy yogurty, sweetness.  Mine?  A Rose Lassi, complete with Rose Petals! Not just amazing, but fun!  If this wasn't enough, Hasan brought us samples of other Lassi combos in small cups to try.  This man knows how to seduce with great taste. Oh. And did I mention the Kheer and Rice Pudding he gave us at the end? 

Over the Top!

As good as Mood Café is, it is a very small shop.  Four tables with bench seats along the wall and plastic stools for everyone else.  So, not the most comfortable arrangement.  It is geared as a take out place, with everything served in take out containers and plastic utensils.  I would be willing to pay more for comfort.  

The sheer enjoyment of the event (yes, this was more than just a cool meal) kicks the experience into 5 Star territory.  In truth, there should be another category available on Yelp that addresses the euphoria and exclamations needed for certain special foodie moments.  

Mood Café would reach that level of extreme amazed unadulterated satisfaction. 

Yeowee!!!

Chaat: Carb salad consists of layers of crunchy deliciousness!
Base: fried crackers/noodles, boiled potatoes, chickpeas, puffed rice
Sauce: sweet, savory, spicy, fruity etc.
Topping: vegetables, samosa, chicken, fruit, etc. 
Sauce and topping varies from chaat to chaat and cook to cook 

If you never had chaat, try it!! It's so different, yet so good! Its crunchy, savory, tangy, and spicy! Talk about a party in your mouth. Its also cold, which I was not expecting, but it also made it very refreshing even with all the different flavors. 

Mood's café specialize in Lassi (yogurt based smoothie) and chaat. It's a great spot for lunch or snack! Definitely come from lassi if chaat is not your cup of tea. In fact, the lassi menu is bigger than chaat menu. All the lassi can be made vegan w/ almond milk, and there are lots of vegetarian options. 

Vegan mango lassi $3.99 - It was very refreshing and not too sweet. I would definitely come back to explore their other 59 flavor combinations. 

Samosa Chaat $5.99 - The portion seems small, but its definitely filling. I wish there was more than 1 samosa though. 

Daal Mash Chaat $6.99 - A little bit more savory than Samosa. I wish there was more of a difference between the two. I felt the only difference was the sauce and samosa. 

Chaat is a popular street food in India, and its awesome that Hassan brought it to West Philly.

I went with a friend to Mood Cafe because we had both been craving some spicy food and were close by. We'd both had chaat before (elsewhere) and wanted to give Mood Cafe a try.

It was definitely worth it. Hassan was a supreme host - asking us our personal taste, if we liked this or that, how spicy we liked our food. The chaat he created was absolutely amazing; full of figs and raisins and radishes and samosas and mango. It was really a work of art and wonderful to watch him create it, talking to us about the food all the while.

I highly recommend the lassi - whether you get a fruit flavored one or a traditional one, they're amazing. He actually created new blends for myself (fig and date) and my friend (mint and honey). It was a perfect place to have a late-afternoon lunch and food conversation. We will definitely be going back.

I took my Pakistani friend from NJ, we drove 2 hours one way to try food in this place which we picked based on numerous positive reviews. 
So friendly, I felt like owner knows us and he tried his best to please us.
I just wanted to say thank you and also my friend told his desserts are very authentic. I would suggest to try Rasmalai.

PHENOMENAL= the mood you will have once you get a chaat and a lassi from this place=) Mood Cafe has such an in-demand reputation, yet it is a humble cafe with such a down-to-earth manager, Hassan, who can easily make anyone feel welcome. I told Hassan that I wanted a lassi and a chaat however he felt was best for a Pakistani food newbie who loves spicy food and lamb. He made me a delicious milk, almond, and date lassi and a chaat that contained spicy, flavorful lamb, yogurt, chick peas, special sauces, and chips that created for a uniquely delicious experience. And to top it off, he threw in a lightly sweet carrot hawla since he wanted me to have a great 1st Pakistani food experience. I think he exceeded his goals. If you're in Philly and in need of a pick-me-up, Mood Cafe will definitely deliver on that.

I like Indian food, but have probably only drank lassi 2 or 3 times in my life. I came here during the miserable heatwave of the summer and saw the line of happy people at Mood Cafe!  I was hungry, but not hungry for a full on meal and walked in sweaty and thirsty.

If you're unfamiliar, according to Wiki lassi is: ablend of yogurt, water, spices and sometimes, fruit. Traditional lassi (a.k.a., "salted lassi", or simply, "lassi") is a savoury drink, sometimes flavoured with ground and roasted cumin. Sweet lassi, however, contains sugar or fruits, instead of spices.

Well, don't fret if you are picky because there is a mind-blowing combination of flavors here.  Literally a wall full of drink combos. Most the the people came for mango, but I went with watermelon. All I can say was it was cool and refreshing with a slight watermelon flavor and hint of spices.  If you are unsure with what you want and order something you can't stomach - they will gladly make you a new drink. You even a get a small cup of the extra.

I got a lassi and samosa and it was under $5! Deal. The veggie samosa was one of the best I have had and totally kills the ones I have eaten in Torrance. I didn't try the chaat and did see people ordering dishes of it to go. Seems like a popular vegetarian spot as well.

This is a friendly neighborhood cafe with kind owners and staff. They really give you service with a smile and believe in the quality of their products. Good find in Philly!

This place is the best. Hassan is one of the nicest people ever, and the lassis are absolutely divine.  I haven't had one that I haven't liked yet...the coconut, mint, strawberry...all delicious.  I have yet to try any of the chaats, but if they're as good as the lassis are, I know I'll be hooked.

My sister brought me to Mood Cafe two weekends ago, and I was delightfully surprised. I spent most of my years in Philly going to Desi Chaat House, which is not too far from Mood Cafe. However, she insisted this was the new spot. 

We arrived right as they opened, and there was already a line. The owner was on the phone trying to fix the computer/credit card machine. He took our orders anyways, and let us eat outside without paying up front - it was very sweet to see a restaurant owner trust their clientele. 

I got the Punjabi Chaat, it was very delicious. I like that he uses larger chunks/crisps compared to Desi Chaat. It's larger chunks of mango, larger pieces of dried samosa, and the portion was perfect. He even let us take the bottle of chutney to add as we ate, whereas other places charge you extra. AND even better it tasted like my mom's chutney and hit very close to home. Loved it.

I also tapped into my sisters Tandoori Chaat which was PHENOMENAL, the chicken was moist and very flavorful. I almost wish I could've had that alone. 

Well done!

Have been wanting to try this place for months and finally made it -- it was worth the wait! Hassan was super friendly and accommodating, took the time to explain the whole menu to us and give us recommendations, said we didn't have to pay if we weren't satisfied (of course we ended up paying because it was amazing!) and even let us try his homemade rose petal essence/reduction. Everything was absolutely delicious, will definitely be back to try the 100 other flavors of chaat and lassis :)
This restaurant is a "must do" every time we visit Philadelphia. Delicious food and great service make the Mood Cafe a great place to be.

Mood Cafe is such a delightful place for a quick meal. 

You basically get to customize your dish which includes an array of spices, flavors and textures. I usually get the samosa combo which is so yummy!!

Everything is made to order, including their lassi's (which can also be made vegan) so plan to wait a few minutes for your order. It's worth the wait!

Omnomnom.

Soooo good! We went in there not really knowing what chaat or lassi were, and the owner - who was so friendly! - gave us a brief rundown and his recommendations. I got the samosa chaat, which had 2 vegetable samosa, chickpeas, potatoes, water chestnuts, mango, lots of different crunchies, and several yummy, if unidentifiable, sauces. We also got a mango lassi and a cardamom lassi, which are like very thin frozen yogurt-based smoothies. Both were excellent. It is deceptively a ton of food, but don't make the mistake of saving the chaat for leftovers like I did - the crunchies get soggy :(
I've been back once for both the chaat and lassi, and I will definitely be back again for the lassi. There are probably about 50 flavors, and if they are at all close to as delicious as the mango and cardamom ones, I will have to try more!
Bonus: I saw this in a couple other yelp reviews and he did it both times we went - he makes more lassi than will fit in a cup, so he gives you the extra in a smaller ~6 oz. cup, so it's perfect for swapping with whoever you go with to try more flavors!
Such a lovely place to grab a quick bite to eat. And mango lassi! What can I say. It's very hard to resist. The owner is such a friendly and warm person. Just makes you happy every time you go.
Food is delicious!! Not oily or fattening - tastes fresh and that's why we come here all the time!!
Amazing selection of Lassi (yogurt) drink. Had Bananas and Dates flavor. It was the best lassi.

We have been here many times, and we love this place! Each time we've been, the owner has a smile on his face and free samples in his hands. He loves introducing customers to new flavors and is clearly working hard to make the business successful. (He even makes vegan lassis now, at the request of his customers.)

Best lassis: mango (my favorite) and banana-date (my wife's favorite)

Also, don't be fooled by the term "shaved ice". It's so much more than ice and one flavor of syrup! He put pineapple, plum, strawberries in mine!

Mood cafe is amazing! It's probably a good thing that I don't live closer or else I would eat every meal here. The owner is always very friendly and helpful; you can tell he really enjoys what he does. All the chaats are great and I love the honey/mint lassi. He even fresh picks the mint out of his garden in front of the store. It doesn't get much better than that. If you haven't tried his desserts, they are great too! Only complaint is that service can be a little slow if there are a lot of people in the store, but I think the food is well worth the wait.
Chaat chaat chaat! This is the best food I think I have ever tasted. The owner is such a friendly guy and he'll make certain that you life whatever you order.

Overall tasty by it did not live up to the Yelp hype. Tasted more like fancy snack food. I dont think i would enjoy this as a meal again. Maybe if i want a snack or a lassi I'd  come back. Parking was a bit of a pain and seating was very limited.

Summary: Tasty snack food. Ambiance feels like more of a snack shop than a restaurant.

I've wanted to try this place out for a while, just due to the reviews on Yelp. I FINALLY GOT TO!!!

Going in, I already knew I wanted a lassi... I'm not new to drinking them.... I grew up eating Indian food, but for some reason, never heard of "Chaat". I had questions. There was a younger man behind the counter, who answered my questions SUPER FAST... On top of the accent, I really couldn't understand him. I wish he'd taken the time to speak slower, and explain. So I felt kinda rushed to make my decision on food.

I got a Chicken Tikka chaat. I've had this kind of Chicken before, so I kinda stayed in my comfort zone. Chaat, is simply all over the place. There are a lot of colors, textures, and tastes involved. Sweet, salty, all kinds of stuff. It was not a distasteful dish, but for me personally, it was just too much going on at once.

I also ordered a vegetable samosa. I am absolutely NOOOO stranger to vegetable samosas. I've been obsessed with eating them since I was little. I basically only like them from one place in NJ. I have tried others, to no avail. Something is always off. But this placed, NAILED IT! They were perfect. I now have 2 places I will eat samosas from.

My lassi. The real reason I stalked this place out. Again, growing up, and still to this day, i loveeee lassi's. I only had mango, and a plain version of Lassi's before. I knew I need to expand my palate, and man will this place help me. My guava lassi was to DIE for. Definitely a key reason in why I will be returning.

On the way out the door, the owner exchanged in small talk with us, and thanked us.

After walking by this place no less than 20 times, a friend recommended that I try the place and I'm so glad I did! The food by itself would be enough to warrant 5 stars, but the owner, Hassan, really goes above and beyond to please his customers. 

I told him that I never had chaat before and it was also my first time to his restaurant. He gave me a brief history of chaat as well as reasons behind why it is so satisfying (texture, balance of flavors, each bite is different than the last.) He asked if I wanted vegetarian or not, spicy or mild, and then got to work. Honestly I was glad not to have to create something myself because there are so many options. Better to let the pro take over. 

Anyway, the end product was this tremendously satisfying mix of mangos, dried cranberries, figs, potatoes, mint sauce, chickpeas, a samosa, and several other ingredients I couldn't make out. It was all delicious! I also got a fig lassi and another couple got a mango lassi. He gave us some of their extra as well as our own extra. The lassi was also, not surprisingly, amazing. 

Bottom line: He won't charge you unless you think the food is amazing, and he absolutely deserves every penny.
Number one place to go!!!!!! We got two chicken chat however mine had black chickpeas cuz i love them. YOU HAVE TO TRY THIS PLACE OUT. Oh and by the way the bathroom has a lota!!!

Its taken me 2 yrs and lots of searching on google images to find this place and remember what it was called! My husband and I came to Philly on a business trip and stopped by this gem 3 times in 24 hours!!! It was soo good! We had the mango, almond,strawberry and pistachio lassi. All amazing! We want them to open a location here in California! The owner reminded me of my dad and the lassi reminded me of my moms. We talk about another visit to Philly just to come back here

My best friend and I went to Mood Cafe today from seeing all the great reviews on Yelp. We were not disappointed. The owner asked if it was our first time and offered to make us food over and over again until we loved it. He said that he wouldn't even settle for mediocre or just okay food.

He explained the history of chaat as a Pakistani street food, the different types of lassi, and even gave us a tutorial on what to expect when we ate it. I would recommend the food here to anyone who likes bold flavors.

The drinks selection is quite good, but the food, not so much.

Stopped by here a short while back to get my mid-afternoon fix, and it was decent, I guess. The lassi/drink selection is really quite good, and I don't think that I've seen such a wide swath of selections outside of Edison, NJ, here in the US. The lassis themselves are well balanced, taste good, and certainly not for those on diets! But they're really good.

The chaats and food selections, not so much. The food is pretty standard stuff, but I really was not a fan of the naans, which is a shame. Further, the chaat items are really not that great - there's other places in the locale that're much better for the food fare.

But, if you're going here just for the drinks, you're in the right place!

As the owner said to us, "Chaat is a party in your mouth"--what a great line! The lassis are creative, ranging from the traditional to outlandish (chocolate raspberry?) and use real fruit/ingredients. Lots of vegetarian options. The owner is super nice and very friendly. He gave us great advice and guided us through our first Chaat experience.

Mood Café was my first chaat experience and it was wonderful! Hassan was incredibly friendly and full of lots of information about the food and lassi -- a wonderful experience all around. Amazing food and people!

I am Indian and think this is some of the most flavorful chaat I have ever eaten. We have a saying that when food is prepared from the heart, it tastes much better. This is definitely true at Mood Cafe. I've never gotten such friendly service. Hasan even has flavors of chaat that are not available in India (a good thing because they're creative fusions that retain the flavorful essence of chaat). The date tamarind lassi is awesome.

Wow, where do I start? I honestly could not have been any more satisfied with my trip to Mood Cafe, and I have never been more confident with this 5-star review. Everything about my visit was just perfect.

Let's start with just walking into the store. I was immediately greeted by the most pleasant owner of the restaurant. After observing that my friend and I were newcomers, he was so helpful with asking what kinds of flavors and ingredients we each liked so that he could customize the perfect first dish for the two of us. I gave up fried foods for lent, which I thought would be difficult for a chaat dish since the base of the dish is fried strips, but the owner told me that they served salads too, so the no-fried-foods restriction wouldn't be a problem at all. I love when restaurants are this accommodating to customer needs.

I wound up ordering a salad chaat with a mango lassi, and my friend got some kind of beef salad chaat with a strawberry lassi. Since it was our first time at the restaurant, the owner told us that if we didn't like the food, had a better chaat at another location, or thought the food was just "okay," our meal would be free. I've never met another man with better customer service. The chaat itself was just wonderful - a wonderful merriment of spiciness and sweetness, crunchiness and chewiness. I will say that chaat in general has very unique and bold flavor, and it's definitely worth a try if you've never had it before, though it may not be ideal for everyone's tastes. Personally, I love chaat, and this dish was probably one of the best, if not the best, that I've had. I could just tell that all of the ingredients (especially the delicious mangoes and dates!) were so fresh, which made my tummy so very happy.

The lassis were amazing as well. I was blinded by how many choices of lassi that there were on the board, but I wanted to stick with the classic mango. It was the perfect sweetness, not overpowering, and had just a hint of tartness from the yogurt. The strawberry lassi was wonderful as well - tasted like a healthier and fresher version of a milkshake. I can't wait to come back and try all of the other delicious combinations and flavors of lassi. Mood Cafe also has vegan options (with coconut milk, almond milk, or soy milk), which is great and a must-try in the future for me too. 

If the food itself isn't great enough, the business owner is one of the greatest humans I've ever met. He is so helpful and genuinely nice, and I felt like throughout the course of my meal, I was able to befriend him and hear so many of his wonderful stories. I asked about many of the unique ingredients and flavors found on his menu, and he was so enthusiastic in explaining to me and even letting me try a lot of his ingredients, such as his sweetened rose petals that are found in the rose lassi. Also, after hearing that my friend had never tried any of the desserts in his fridge (rice pudding, carrot halwa, and gulab jamun) before, he gave us samples of each! It was such a nice gesture and so uncommon nowadays in restaurants. It was so refreshing to find a restaurant that I genuinely love going into now.

There is no doubt in my mind that I will be back at Mood Cafe, even though it is a trek from Penn's campus. Lassi in the summer just sounds absolutely wonderful, but what I'm looking forward to the most is being able to talk to that wonderful man again.

Came here with a girl.

Ordered some lassi's and a veggie chaat. I loved the rose and mango lassi drinks (smoothies). The chaat was interesting with some strong spicy flavors even though it was on the lower end of the spiciness level but I really enjoyed it.

Very healthy choices and Hasan was very helpful, friendly and very generous. Something you do not find a whole lot of, so I appreciated that about this place. There's only enough seats (along the storefront window) for about 4 people + chairs and they bring out the outdoor patio tables and chairs in May (after winter) so it'd be nice to eat outdoors. This place did seem like an order-to-go spot. Saw a lot of people come in and take their orders to-go.

I'd definitely go back and try out the other lassi's. It does contain yogurt so if you're lactose intolerant, you might want to take that into consideration. 

Also, this is not just a vegetarian/vegan spot, though that is what they primarily have, they also serve certain chaat dishes with different kinds of meats.

It's neighborhood street parking here so it's best if you took pub transportation or if you're close enough, walk (it didn't seem too ghetto).

Oh yeah, West Philly.

Parking: Street
Price: $4-$8
Wait: 5 mins after ordering
The food is flavorful, textually exciting and pleasing delicious. We will have to come back to try others from their huge menu.

After stopping by numerous times for a wonderful mango lassi (honestly, the best I have ever had), I finally tried the chaat and oh my goodness what a delightful experience! The owner explained it as a dish that is savory, sweet, sour, and spicy all in one and he is absolutely right! I am not sure which one precisely I ordered, as I told him that I wanted something spicy and with chicken. So I got a salad chaat with spicy chicken (though that is not specifically listed on their menu), based off his recommendation. It was truly wonderful. It consisted of salad greens, two types of chickpeas, spicy pieces of chicken, cranberries, mango chunks, radishes, yogurt sauce, mint chutney, and some fried dough strips that had a curry flavor. I have never had anything like this. Will definitely be back for more chaat!

Probably the biggest downside is that there isn't really anything warm to eat or drink on the menu. The lassis and the chaat are both cold and thus not optimal in wintertime. I wish he offered some warm tea!

I wish I could give this place 6 stars, it's that amazing. Hassan is the most gracious, nicest business owner I've ever met. The food and drinks are simply amazing. Not to mention the value this place brings. We got 4 drinks, 5 meals for less than $60. Hassan also mixed us up an extra drink and cups to sample more different lassis because we were first timers. He catered our meals to our tastes and asked us questions about what we liked and catered it to the 5 senses. I came all the way from San Diego to sample this amazing cuisine and I will definitely be back and bring friends too. Hassan is an artist, he made the drinks and food very artistic and the taste is nothing I've ever had and I've traveled all over the world to sample local cuisines. He took traditional Indian food and made it a fusion of new flavors. He also explained to us in detail how he created certain sauces like the green sauce had so many fresh, unique ingredients in it that were too many for me to remember. 

Simply amazing. Fantastic food and service. A+++++

Excellent experience at the Mood Cafe! A couple running buddies and I stumbled upon this gem out of the blue, and the food was delicious and affordable! The owner was SO NICE... You could tell he put his heart and soul to the menu! I'm not often in West Philly, but I may need to swing by more often, because I will definitely start getting cravings for the Mood Cafe chaat and lassi!

The chaat here is so diverse, and seems very legitimate compared to other chaat houses in the area (like Desi Chaat House). There are different styles based on different regionally areas and different dietary restrictions.

I got the Punjabi Chaat, which was a vegetarian one. It mixed in the spices and sweet flavors all together perfectly. The servings are big, so you get a lot for a good price. I also got the classic drink, which was mango lassi (there were plenty of other flavors too though). The mango lassi was phenomenal - I've never tasted anything creamier. The guy gives you huge servings too! 

My only qualm is I wish the owner had explained each chaat better because the boards don't make the ingredients as clear as I would've hoped, and so I was left very confused.

Mood cafe is my favorite place to grab a quick snack or dinner after a long day of work. The owner Hassan is so friendly and creates a welcoming environment. You can hang out outdoors at high top tables or indoors to enjoy some tunes and a/c. My favorite things to order are Samosa chaat, Chicken Tikka chaat, and the rice pudding. There are also so many combinations of fruit to make an awesome Lassi (smoothie). I have always had a positive experience here and the food and service keep bringing me back!

Incredible find! Not your typical desi/Indian food. Highly recommended if you want to try something different. Several variations of the plain old lassi and a personalized take on the "Chaat" format. Down to earth, super-friendly service. Highly recommend the Rose Lassi as well as the Cardamom Lassi.

I love this place.  It's amazing how a mish-mash of a million different flavors and textures comes together and tastes so fabulous.  Seriously, it's like  a symphony.

I must admit the first time I had chaat I was not impressed.  On a whim and with a deep craving (who gets cravings for something they don't like?!?) I declared that I absolutely had to go back.  And boy was i glad that I did.

As most others have said Hasan is perhaps one of the nicest business owners in The City of Brotherly Love.   The strawberry lassi is my new favorite, the samosas are incredible (especially when dressed up with the sauces) and the crazy chicken chaat is like a modern art project both to look at and to taste.

If you've never had it before let them know, you'll get a brief lesson in all things chaat.

5.0/5 

The lassi's at Mood Cafe aren't just good; they're heavenly. What's more, there's more flavors than you could ever imagine. Upon entering the cafe, you're immediately greeted by a huge chalkboard with a listing of 60 lassi and "lassi combination" flavors. There are your standard options -- like mango -- but also many more incredibly unique and exciting flavors to try: rose, apple fig, date almond, spicy mint, "salty queen" (this one's a bit of an enigma), orange papaya, peaches & cream...

But it doesn't stop there. The owner, Hassan, actually initially made a menu of 140 items, until he realized that customers were suffering from decision paralysis. If you ask, he'll craft an off-menu lassi custom made for you. After learning that I like nuts, he made me one of his own personal favorites, "almond pistachio with a dash of cardamom". It -- and each of the ~8-10 flavors I've tried so far -- was DELICIOUS. I would go so far as to describe Hassan's lassi combinations as an experience, not just a drink. In the first sip, you're hit with the whirlwind of different flavors in your mouth. It's surprising, so you sip again. Perhaps the flavor gives you an immediate joy, or perhaps you're not sure what to think. Nonetheless, you're intrigued. So you sip again. Soon enough, with sip after sip, you begin unraveling the complex tastes of the drink, until it gains a familiarity that makes the flavor even more delicious with every sip.

Protip: If you like the yogurt flavor of traditional lassi's, ask for a yogurt base. If you prefer something more like a juice smoothie, ask for a juice base.

Besides the tastiness of the drinks, I'd also like to note that the owner Hassan is incredibly friendly. Every time I've gone with friends, he'll give us an extra sample cup with each of our drinks so that we can trade and try each other's flavors. He promises not to charge us if we don't like our drink, though we've never done that of course because every drink is delicious. The last time I went, he even gave my friend and I extra sample cups from a different customer's custom drink, so that we could try a new flavor he had never made before, "rose mint". (This one's particularly special because it's made from rose and mint that Hassan grew himself!) Mood Cafe's massive menu is something Hassan has incredible fun with, and you can see it in the delight on his face when he gets to combine different ingredients in new and interesting ways.

While I usually go to Mood Cafe for the lassis, the chaat is also pretty tasty. Warning: If you ask for "very spicy", it's ACTUALLY very spicy, not your typical Americanized "very spicy". I consider myself to have a fairly okay spice tolerance, and I absolutely died. Thank goodness I had the lassi to save me from the fire ^^;; On the other hand, I didn't find the "medium spicy" to be spicy at all.

In summary, would highly highly recommend, especially the lassi combinations! And if you have the time, be sure to strike up a conversation with the owner too -- he's super friendly!

All I can say is "wow."
I'm a BIG fan of Indian food, but I had never had a chaat til today, and let me tell you, all these Indian restaurants got Indian food wrong. This is some real, down-home cookin', IndiPak style. I wandered in alone after a random tip, and, man, was it amazing. 

The fresh-squeezed juices are AMAZING (try something you've never had before -- watermelon juice is just incredible), the owner taught me a lot about Indian food and cooking in general, and everything was out of this world. Oh, and they're vegan friendly!

My recommendation: go in with $10, ask the owner for a chaat of his choice and a lassi with your favorite fruit (forget mango, way to common), and, if it's not busy, talk to the owner the whole time you're eating. I promise, you WON'T be disappointed.

This place is amazing. Delicious, affordable food that's filling but doesn't leave you bloated afterward. The paneer chaat is my favorite. If you're getting a lassi, cardamom was delicious (try it vegan sometime too!).

Mood Cafe is not located in the most happening location, but it is definitely worth the visit. I have never had Chaat before, and honestly I still dont know what it is besides the fact that it is street food. The owner was super friendly and sweet. For those that know what Chaat is, it can be customizable. Since I had no idea what to even put in it, the owner asked me a series of questions, then proceeded to make me something he thought i would like. It was delicious. There were so many different textures and flavors to explore with each bite. 

The lassi here is THE BEST! They have an array of flavors. If you can, please eat there! Whenever customers order lassi there is always leftovers, so the owner will kindly pour some into cups and bring it over to dine in customers for them to try. While I was eating there, I seriously tried like 4-5 different kinds of lassi that other people ordered. I had to bring my own lassi home because I was so full!

The owner also has a policy of not paying unless you are satisfied. My friend wanted to pay after we ordered, but the owner said we should eat it first to make sure we like it, then pay. Seriously, the best customer service I've ever experienced. Too bad I discovered this place too late, I was only able to eat here 3 times before I had to go back to Boston. If I am ever back in Philly, I will definitely visit this place again!
If you're reading this review get your ass to this establishment rn and get yourself some chaat and a cucumber mint lassi  EXCELLENT service and SUPER TASTY food. 12/10 recommend.

I made a yelp account specifically so I could write this review.  I experienced the best restaurant experience and service of my life here. The food was really good.  I have never had chaat or lassis before, but the owner descriptively told me what I would taste/experience and accommodated the fact it was my first time at the restaurant.  

Hands down, the best part about my experience at Mood Cafe was the owner.  He welcomed me and made me feel right at home.  He not only made delicious food, he made sure my first experience was a great one.  Most importantly, he wanted to make sure I had enjoyed the food I was eating. He recommended a basic chaat for my first time, but wanted to make sure it was to my satisfaction to if I wanted to more/less spicy he wanted to adjust it.  Accompanied with good conversation, it turned this little hole-in-the-wall restaurant into one of the best experiences I have ever had.  Mood Cafe is a must go if you are an adventurous eater and like good service.

GO HERE.

Seriously--we were blown away with Mood Cafe. Walking in, you got the sense that the proprietor couldn't wait to tell you about chaat: he is to this celebrated south Asian street food what Bubba from "Forrest Gump" is to shrimp. Before we knew it, we were dancing around his dizzying selection. "But don't worry," he said. "If you don't like, you won't pay."

That wasn't a problem. We got the chicken tikka chaat, the panir chaat and the samosa chaat. They were all incredible, with layer on layer of flavors and fresh ingredients that you won't sort out before you get full, which you will, because the portions are quite generous. 

To my surprise, my favorite was the panir chaat. Rather than the usual (and somewhat boring) tofu-like blocks of curd, this chaat was suffused with a crumbly, golden cheese with a flavor similar to burrata. It wasn't awash in the stuff--just enough to get the flavor through without feeling heavy. It was perfect.

We came at an off hour, with no other customers in sight, and the proprietor seemed to be getting a kick out of blowing our minds. He kept giving us stuff on the house. I had not even mentioned the word "Yelp," so this was really just kindness. We tried his carrot halva, which Heather loved--I thought it was too sweet--and his oh-so-decadent rice pudding.

The lassis we ordered each came with a side cup (as seen in some of the user photos), meaning that we could each have some of one another's lassi. I got the almond pistachio with a dash of cardamom, and Heather got papaya. Heather thought her papaya was a bit too yogurt-forward at the start, but found that it grew on her. I thought that mine was perfect, and had to cut myself off.

The entire order was $33, and we each got two and a half meals out of it. Even excluding the generous samples that we enjoyed, that's pretty damned good--especially for a place with such wonderful food and service.

I'm going to add on to the 5 star reviews because this place is awesome.  I had zero experience with chaat, but when I was in the area and did a yelp search for restaurants, I had to try it.  The owner is super friendly and will guide you through the process of making your meal.  I'm not exactly sure what all was in it, but I got the crazy chicken, which had two types of chicken, mango, potatoes, crunchy rice strips, and lots of sauces and spices.  It really is totally unique, and a beautiful presentation.  The portion is large too, could only eat half.  I also grabbed a samosa on its own, and it was really good.  It came with chick peas and some sauce.  For my lassi I went with banana and fig.  It was super tasty.  I took my order to go, but there is some seating inside.  I definitely recommend taking the trip to West Philly to give Mood Cafe a try.

The owner of the restaurant works there all the time and is very friendly. He always has suggestions for newcomers to chaat, and is oftentimes correct about his predictions about what people would enjoy.

I am not a big yogurt fan, but I love the peanut butter lassie. I told the owner that I was not a fan of the original lassie, and he said he could make me one I would enjoy. He was correct, and he gave me more than the standard amount. 

The food is fresh and made to order, and cheap to boot. 
Highly recommend!

Mood Cafe is as close to perfect as you're going to get.  Being chaat rookies, we didn't know what to order....not an issue here.  The owner asks a few questions and starts piling things into a bowl.  This may concern some less adventurous eaters, but after three tries now, we've gotten three different chaats and all of them were excellent.  

I don't really know how to properly describe the food other than:  rice puffy, chewy, nutty, somewhat spicy, somewhat sweet-y, fruity, yogurt-y, crunchy, veggie perfection.  The service is super friendly (every time without fail) and the lassis are solid as well.  Do yourself a favor and head over here on Sunday, grab a chaat to go, and head down to the park for the farmer's market.

Another great shop on Baltimore Ave. My boyfriend and I stopped in for an early dinner on the weekend. There was no one inside, but the man sitting outside (who I later realized was the owner) nodded and smiled to us through the window. The person who came out to take the order was very helpful when we asked for help with the menu, which consisted of 6 different lassi flavors, and about 20 variations of chaat. All lassis can be made vegan, and there are plenty of vegetarian chaat choices. There is also the option of a salad chaat. The space inside is very small--there's a counter and a few seats, and a couple refrigerators of drinks and desserts.

We ended up ordering a mango lassi (they suggested starting with the classic before trying flavors such as cucumber mint), a samosa chaat, and a Punjabi chaat. While we were waiting for our food, the owner came in. He boasted that they had the best mango lassi (or it's free) and explained what a chaat was. (It is made of a lot of components. I remember potatoes, mangoes, radishes, chickpeas, crunchy fried dough strips, mint sauce...) He was so friendly and so passionate about the food. He also gave us a mango lassi sample after hearing that we'd only ordered one.

We sat outside to eat. The lassi (my first one) was delicious--cool and creamy with just the right amount of sweetness and a lot of mango flavor. It was also very helpful for managing the spice of the chaat, which we ordered at a medium spice level. The chaat was crunchy, flavorful, and filling. Some of the sauces and components are sweet (I was reminded of craisins), some savory, and some spicy. There were crunchy bites and soft bites. Everything tasted fresh and yummy!

I look forward to returning soon!

I come here a lot and they already know what i want! Medium spicy chicken salad chaat!! Love love! It's a combination of different flavors that just blends and tastes amazing! 

Another fav of mine is the papaya lassi!! I tried the mango but i love papaya lassi more!

I am hooked indeed :)

Visited the mood cafe twice in its first week of operation.  Lassis are amazing.  I'll second another reviewer's plug for the triple berry lassi.  

Hassan, the owner, is a super enthusiastic guy who is really proud of his product.  He talked to us at length about how much he loved being able to have a business that served lots of different types of fresh juice.  He let us try the carrot juice, grape juice and we bought OJ.  The grape juice is a little too sweet, but who knows: maybe my taste buds just miss welch's preservatives?  I'm no vegetable lover, but carrot juice is HELL of refreshing, and I expect to hit it up many times this summer.

chaat: i'm not an expert but i'll try to describe this mix of delicious. i had the dhokla and it was amazing.  the breadish thing at the bottom is midway between spongecake and cornbread.  on top of that is a mix of yogurt, pretty colored sauces, potatoes, and (i don't know) lots of other things that combine to make a taste that is at once tangy, sweet and savory.  

go to there.

Legit, but all the chaats i tasted were essentially exactly the same with like chicken or beer or a samosa added to it. Still amazing flavors. Particularly loved the dates. I guess he could tell I was new and didn't want to confuse it up that much. 

Melon lassi was toppppp notch. Place is so close to 5 stars. Ill definitely go back and try to get a little more diversity with my chaats

Mood cafe is pretty awesome. If you are into chaat, you MUST go here. My friend and I opted for the samosa chaat and we were quite happy. The amount of flavor packed into these dishes is incredible - I LOVE tamarind...mmmmmm

I will say that the spice level (at least for us ) was a little lower than expected. I ordered my usual medium and probably could have taken it up a notch.

Heck yea, Mood!! Bringing the heat... And accompanying that heat with yogurt if you are like me and can't handle the heat. 
The owner is super nice, the chaat is ON POINT! I had no idea what chaat even was, and this was a perfect introduction. I tried ordering one of the crazy named chaats, and he suggested that he just make me an introduction chaat and when I become a regular I will try them all! 
I've had lassi in New York and haven't liked it, here at Mood I have already drank two on my first visit. I will most definitely be back.
Tips:
Cucumber mint lassi 
Rose lassi
And let the chaat chef work his magic!!!

Hassan is the Sultan of Chaats!

It's sparkling clean, and Hassan ALWAYS greets you with a smile, no matter how busy he is!  He always remembers you, and all I need to say is... "I'd like a crunchy Chaat", and he just knows what I like!

The Samosas are absolutely ridiculously yummy!  They are actually mini-chaats, and if you've never had a Chaat, but know you like Samosas, try one!  It will give you a taste of what a Chaat is all about!

The Lassis... oh... the Lassi's!!!  I've tried quite a few of the different flavors, but I always come back to the Honey Mint, soooo delicious, and refreshing!  AND HE CAN MAKE THEM VEGAN!

The fruit ice's are something you MUST try in the summer.  I would suggest to ask to try a little taste of the sandalwood syrup before you order one with that.  I happen to love it, but it is an acquired taste to some.  He's always willing to let you try things first.  

Ohhhhh and the desertssssss...  
The Kheer... seriously... if you even remotely like Kheer, try his!  It's thick, flavorful like nothing I've had before.  It has the consistency of my Gram's rice pudding from when I was a kid!  

I really just can't say enough about my love for Mood Cafe!!!


(... now I want a chaat... guess where I'm going for lunch???!! )
This place rocks. The people that work there are so nice and make you feel special and it's delicious. There is absolutely no reason why you shouldn't spend all of your money there constantly.

it tastes really really weird, and not in a good way. Besides the owner is very passionate at first, I told him this is the first time I try this, he told me mine is free, I was so moved I gave him $20 as tip, but in the end he asked me to pay. It not that i care about the dollars, but it was really embarrassed when he asked when I tried to go. I won't come back.

I would give this place a five-star rating for either the food quality or the excellent service alone, but when you put it all together, I wish I could dub this place an exceptional six on a scale of five.

The ingredients are homemade and freshly prepared. The flavors are bright, complex and authentic. Best of all, the owner (who is also the chef and the only employee) is SO happy to share his profound love of his craft with anyone who walks in the door, and his excitement is contagious. You can taste it in the food... of which, by the way, he will generously give you a preposterous amount of free samples.

It's obvious that he's doing this because he loves it and not for the money, and it's just so nice to be around that kind of energy. That, paired with the tastebud-popping mix of flavors and textures, are has what kept this small business afloat despite trying economic times. The prices are so reasonable I really wonder if he's actually losing money on it.

Take it from a lifetime Philadelphia native: Mood Cafe is one of Philly's most special, and secret, treasures. You would be doing yourself a serious disservice to miss checking it out.

The owner is super nice and so helpful! You can tell he does this because he loves this. The chaat was different from what you normally get, I really liked the mango and dried cranberries in mine. The chutneys are very authentic. Very reasonably priced and so good! Try the mango lassi and bhel pori or papdi chaat
Amazing food...amazing lassi's...Hassan is a great host.

It was a little overwhelming when we walked into Mood Cafe and saw 60 lassi options and about as many options for chaats (which we'd never tried before), but Hassan was quick to alleviate our obvious first-timer concerns. 

He asks you what you've had before, what flavors of fruit/spices/etc. you like, and offers up suggestions based on his most popular lassis. And best of all, assures you not to worry because if you don't like it, he'll make you a different one at no extra charge. We were given the same guarantee for chaats, which rather than ordering off of the board, he simply made to our preferences with respect to heat level, etc. As promised, the chaats were a strange but perfectly orchestrated blend of flavors and textures: spicy, sweet, crunchy, creamy, salty... an unexpected symphony of deliciousness and variety.

It's clear that Hassan is a businessman who justs GETS IT. He even says that the reason he'll replace anything you don't like is because he wants you to enjoy your food/drink so that you come back, which is the type of common sense/logic that many restaurants somehow fail to use. Not only will we be going back, but we'll tell all of our friends and family how great the food and service was. Hassan's style is simple, smart, and much appreciated by the consumer.

Will undoubtedly be regular spot for my girlfriend and I, seeing as we're now hooked on chaats and only have 983987 more menu options to try.

In town for a weekend getaway and having no knowledge of the local food scene, I came across Mood Cafe while searching. Good reviews, excellent photos and decent prices brought me in, and I couldn't have been happier with my choice. Thank you again, Yelp, for steering me to such a great find in the city of brotherly love.

Mood Café had some seriously high reviews.. a solid 5 star rating with close to 250 reviews, so they've got to be doing something right. They serve a dish called Chaat here.. something I've never heard of and something that I figured I might as well try. 

This place is much smaller than I expected. No real sitting area, but they have a couple of makeshift tables and plastic stools for people who want to eat there. Plastic forks, knives and napkins sit by the door as a "grab your own" kind of thing. You place your order at the counter and they prepare it in plastic to go containers.

Having no clue what I wanted, I told the guy behind the counter that I was in town for the night, saw they had some great reviews on Yelp, and I wanted to see what it was all about. He explained one of the menus was yogurt based smoothies and the other was the chaat. He also helped steer me by asking if I wanted vegetarian or the type of protein I wanted. 

I think I should point out that I had no clue what chaat was and really still don't. I know it has a lot of tasty sauces.. some crunchy bits and fresh mango in it. Mine had the Chicken Tikka in it too, because that's what I ordered. There were some items in my dish that were cold and some that were hot. Some bits were crunchy and some bits were not. While I cannot tell you exactly what it was (or if it was authentic like some reviews claim it is not) I can tell you it was delicious and I ate every bite of it.

I also ordered the blueberry lassi and was really happy with it. A friend ordered the mango and we were each given a full glass of what we ordered and a smaller cup with the other one so we could taste it. I thought this was a really nice gesture and was very appreciative of it.

I'd love to tell all of my friends about Mood Café and haul them all to Philly to give it a try, but there wouldn't be enough room in the place for everyone. Instead, I can only share my experience and hope it steers you inside on some cold and rainy night as it did me.

FINALLY! I properly tried Mood Cafe, after having their Mango Lassi and Samosas for the Baltimore Avenue Dollar stroll over the summer.
The menu has changed so if you're in the mood for chaats , you can go to Mood Cafe. He has as many chaats as the sister restaurant Desi Chaat House. I was hungry for Chicken Chaat. This was made medium spicey. It was delicious! Nice pieces of Tandoori chicken with other yummy treats mixed together! (chick peas, potato, mango, red onion, lentils and spices and crisps.The flavors all mix nicely together and tastes delectable in your mouth! very satisfying and filling and yummy.

 Now Mood Cafe also has 5 Indian dishes with rice (Daal, Saag Paneer , etc) Plus, several Lassis and some Indian Desserts. It was relaxing and the Owner is very nice! I live closer to Mood cafe than Desi Chaat House,so, now I think I will stop here when in the mood for chaat! 

I definitely will be back, for chaat and Indian dishes.

Full disclosure: I've grown up eating chaat and other tea time snacks, and when we tried (and failed) to eat at Kilimindjaro for dinner last night, we ended up at Mood anticipating that we'd be leaving still wanting a full meal. 

How wrong we were. 

There's not much seating here, and parking's a bit of a pain. Once we had that sorted out, we ordered: fig lassi, rose lassi, bhel puri, and a lamb dish. We tried to order one more chaat, but Hassan assured us that he would put the lamb on a salad, making it one of his salad chaats, and that we would have more than enough food. He was right. 

I love rose flavored drinks and desserts, the boo does not however, as he finds the flavor to be overpowering. Not so with the rose lassi - just the right amount of that subtle hint of flavor. The fig was fantastic, too - and Hassan's blender makes more than what fits into the plastic smoothie glasses, so you'll get an extra plastic cup filled with bonus lassi. 

The bhel puri was unlike anything we've had before. Traditionally, it's a dish with puffed rice, sev (crunchy thin noodle-like), potatoes, chickpeas, coriander, and onions. You can top it off with either coriander based or tamarind based chutney. Hassan takes artistic license with his bhel puri chaat - in addition to all of the traditional components, there was some hot sauce, mango, fig, and yogurt. Looking at it, I was confused as to how all of those things would work together, but don't question the magic, it was absolutely delicious.  

The lamb salad chaat was a similarly confusing, but ultimately delicious experience. The lamb had the right texture to hold together in a salad, and had a nice cumin flavor to it. 

As we were among the last customers, all of us in the restaurant got a free dessert. Folks, even if we had to pay for it, that rice pudding/khir was amazing - the rice was so tender, and the pudding perfectly sweet. 

Can't wait for our next adventure here!

I kid you not, whenever I go to Philadelphia, regardless of where I am in the city, I will hop a train to Mood and get my fix. No need to look at the menu. Just ask the friendly owner to prepare you something wonderful along with a lassi of whatever is in season and complementary, and he will take care of the rest. The location is unassuming and the prices are beyond fair. but candidly, I'm just thankful his location is in Philly and not Pakistan, because it's saving me a lot in airfare.

First things first, the food is really good. Enjoyed by Chicken Chaat and Strawberry Lassi. The other thing is that the owner is so nice. I was a klutz and dropped my Lassi on the way out the door. Literally spilled it on their front step. The owner felt bad for me and made me another one right away. I offered to pay for it and he wouldn't let me. Another worker cleaned up the mess on the front step before I could attempt to leave a second time. All in all, great food and great service.

I had wanted to venture into Mood so many times before, and finally made it happen on a random Saturday afternoon.  I was excited to try the place everyone had been talking about since I moved here some 5 years ago.  Unfortunately, what I received, was nothing like what had been described.  I took my friend of Indian descent as he knew what we should order (I, admittedly, have no clue as to Indian food).  He ordered three different chaats with varying ingredients and spice levels.  While the sauces had good flavor, the ingredients didn't seem to match.  I felt like I was eating thrown-together ingredients with no real connection to each other or the sauces.  My friend said the person preparing the chaats didn't particularly know what he was doing.  

Considering this place is on the other side of the city for me, I probably won't go back.  The flavors just weren't there.

Mood cafe is my favorite West Philly dining option.  The chaat is unlike anything I have ever tasted - a perfect combination of sweet, salty, crunchy, spicy...somehow it all fits together.  If you haven't tried it Hassan will make you one and let you try it before you pay.

Tonight I had a new favorite - one of the meals with rice, lentils, indian pickle, and yoghurt.  It was unique and delicious!!

To top it all off, Mood has INCREDIBLE lassis, vegan lassis, juices, and special desserts.  The lassis are amazing with fresh fruit in pretty much any combination you want.  Also, even though I'm not vegan, I love the vegan lassis.  They are made with soy milk, almond milk, fruit, and ice--more like a smoothie and lighter than the regular lassis.  Perfect if you are full from eating a chaat!

Aside from the food being incredibly fresh, unique, and always delicious, the service at Mood makes you feel like a special guest.  Tonight, I ordered a vegetarian lentil meal, and Hassan let me try another vegetarian option as well just because he thought I'd like it.  His hospitality made the whole experience extra special.

Check Mood out - you'll love it!

The absolute best thing about Philadelphia. I, too, found out about Mood Cafe on Yelp and was skeptical even though it has so many good ratings, but I tried it and I have been addicted ever since. Hassan (the owner) said that being addicted to his chaats is worse than being addicted to drugs since the only place you can get his chaats is on this street corner in West Philly. I have brought numerous people with me to eat here and not one person has not liked it--they all loved it. Do your self a favor, forget about any doubts you may be having regarding this place, and GO! NOW! Also: SO affordable!

This place is great. I passed by here so many times before and always noticed the bright and sunny interior. We came in one night at like 9pm, and the owner was so nice and friendly. 

As it turns out, their lassi is the bomb. Order the banana - and you will find yourself in heaven.

Just in time for summer! Mood Cafe is here to bring us cool tasty refreshingness. This place really fills an interesting niche- I would go here for the ice cream alone, but of course they also serve FRESH squeezed juices, lassi's and chaat and assorted other treats. I loved the Indian style tutti-frutti and saffron ice creams (both of which I was given samples!). The American style chocolate, strawberry, almond butter(!), and more were all DELICIOUS. And I say this as an ice cream connoiseur. The fresh juices also make it a dangerous spot for me- watermelon, mango, carrot, nothing's better in the heat. They're open in the evening's when you want to go for a stroll and have a destination, and there's always going to be something new and exciting to try- something for every mood. Plus, you can hang around at the two outdoor tables or indoor window seating and watch the neighborhood while you have a chaat. Enjoy!

Before I moved further West I was a regular client at Desi Chaat living just 1 block away (I'd eat their food 3-5 times a week). Chaat became an obsession of mine. Nowadays I live right next to Mood Cafe and it has become a local favorite of mine (for good reason). The owner, Hassan, is a good man who aims to please and has never once lets me down. I often stop by after class not bothering to look at the menu and always asking about any new creations or concoctions as I love to explore and try new tastes and flavors. 

Fair warning, there is no kitchen on premises so don't expect the meals to be made in front of you from scratch and magically served within minutes. I love and recommend the samosas (with all the fixings on them) and I always ask for a nice kick of a spice. Hassan often tells new clients of his money back guarantee if your not pleased but I have yet to see anyone take him up on it. What I really love about Mood Cafe and why I happily give it 5 stars is because of the menu; it isn't stale or rigid, rather more of work of art, dynamic and ever-evolving. The other reason is because it's one of the few places that takes me serious when I say I want "back home" spicy spicy, NOT white man spicy ;-). hehehe

I love bringing people here because chaat is so different from what they've had before. 

The lassis are fantastic.

Incredible food and drinks! Got the mango lassi and samosa chaat and was definitely more than impressed. Was also very excited to hear that the owner plans to expand the menu to include more food. Owner was very kind and passionate, and took the time to explain some of the new things that are coming up on their menu. As someone from Karachi I'm particularly excited about trying the Sindhi biryani! They also have really nice outside seating. Definitely a must visit when in Philly!

I LOVE LOVE LOVE the Mood Cafe!  I have never been a big fan of lassis, but I had heard that they were particularly good here, so I thought I'd give it a try.

I walked in, saw the fresh pineapples on display and decided to get a pineapple lassi. Hassan suggested I try a mint and honey one instead. I said sure.  Not only did he make the mint and honey lassi, but then he made the pineapple lassi as well so I "wouldn't worry that I had missed out."  Needless to say they were both so insanely delicious that I ended up drinking two lassis for dinner that night, a decision I do not regret (although I do feel slightly ashamed- I could not stop drinking them they were so delicious!).  So yes, two lassis for three dollars that night! 

I left VERY satisfied!

What can I say? I walked in the door a little skeptical but the friendly owner had me at ease in no time. Since I was a newbie he explained the "two" things they serve - lassi and chaat. Don't be fooled by that though, they have many, many variations of each. I had the chaat which is prepared based on your mood and taste after a quick consultation. The ingredients don't really make sense but believe me, the end result is amazing! You will love it and immediately plan your next visit.

My friend suggested that we stop into the Mood Cafe and even though I had no idea what a lassi was I decided to give it a try.  My friend wasn't sure if she wanted peach or blueberry but the owner told her that he'd make it for her and if she didn't like it he'd make her the other one.  She ended up loving the peach that he made for her.  

When it came to my turn I went for the strawberry and whenever I told him that I'd be splitting it with my girlfriend he added more into the mixture, making enough to fill both of our glasses because, as he said he "didn't want us to fight" over one person having more than the other.  The lassi was reasonably priced and tasty and he is just such a nice guy.  I would definitely recommend it!

This was my first time trying Pakistani food! Chaat is very interesting - every bite gives you a different flavor due to the different layers incorporated into the dish. I tried the samosa chaat (the samosa was delicious!) and the dish was great! Know that this dish isn't hot (temperature-wise), the samosa or whatever add on you get is warm but the base is chickpeas and potatoes and they are cooked but not hot.
